Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Sequence-based Classification of Fungi; June 12-13, 2014 - East Langing, MI
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award to Pennsylvania State University is made to support a workshop to discuss and develop a community plan for a DNA sequence-based classification of fungi. A large proportion of fungal diversity is only known from DNA sequence fragments, but these taxa cannot be incorporated within current classification systems because their scientific names are not associated with a physical specimen. This workshop will consider the various technical, analytical and taxonomic/nomenclatural challenges and opportunities for implementing a DNA sequence-based taxonomy of fungi.

The workshop will be two days in length and will include a total 40 participants. Participants will include researchers from diverse career stages and types of institution, with at least ten students and post-doctoral researchers, including members from under-represented groups, expected to participate. Workshop management will be handled by a steering committee of six individuals including three women, two faculty from Principally Undergraduate Institutions, and two people from under-represented groups. The workshop will result in: 1) a broadly distributed meeting report, 2) a position paper to be submitted for publication in a peer-reviewed journal, and 3) a proposal to modify the International Code for Algae, Fungi and Plants to allow sequence-based classification of fungi. Recommendations from this workshop will not only provide a framework for the classification of fungi using DNA sequence data, but will also serve as a model for the classification of other taxa known only from DNA sequences such as microbes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Twenty-nine systematists, ecologists, plant pathologists, students, and bioinformaticians met on June 12-13, 2014, in East Lansing, Michigan (USA), to ponder the complexities of DNA sequence-based classification (SBC) and identification (SBI) in Fungi. The goals of the workshop were to (1) develop a blueprint for the establishment and promotion of community standards and protocols for classification of fungi using diverse DNA sequence data, (2) facilitate molecular studies of the environment that involve bioinventories of fungal community members, and (3) serve as a model for adapting classification tools to next-generation studies of microbial biodiversity.

This meeting considered the challenges and opportunities presented by new methods and datasets on both SBI and SBC in Fungi.  The challenges lie in the volume of data being provided in nucleic acid-based surveys of environments, and available methods for gleaning taxonomic information from them in a way that is both useful in ecological studies (SBI) and adds meaningfully to taxonomic knowledge (SBC). Unexploited opportunities exist in these nucleic acid datasets both for SBI and SBC. In recent years, broad new fungal taxa (for example, the Class Archaeorhizomycetes) have been discovered in the fungal kingdom based on environmental sequence data, and this is particularly important for classification of obligately biotrophic fungi (e.g., unculturable obligate symbionts of plants such as the ectomycorrhizal Glomeromycota). But even with these dramatic examples of success in SBI and SBC, a great deal of under-utilized taxonomic information lies in the massive volume of data being provided in next-generation sequence-based analyses.

Several themes and recommendations emerged from the meeting (Herr et al. 2014). Importantly, it was recognized that the challenges are both technical and social. The technical challenges lie in the need for curated databases with quality annotation that would facilitate and guide SBI and SBC. Perhaps more daunting are questions about defining data standards, linking data and metadata, reproducibility, and community compliance with best practices. The group considered the strengths and weaknesses of several existing database models for microorganisms, including the Ribosomal Database Project, Silva, GreenGenes, UNITE and MaarjAM; all of these databases have documented utility in both SBI and SBC, and have shown rapid growth in recent years. These curated databases circumvent the problems presented by the flood of unidentified or poorly identified sequences found in the International Nucleotide Sequence Database Collaboration (INSDC), but their care and maintenance requires a great deal of time, and there are limited common standards.

The group put forward the following specific recommendations, with the goal of improving fungal SBI and SBC in ways that maximize its impact across diverse disciplines:

1)   Develop community standards for taxon definition: It is recognized that a “one size fits all” approach is not desirable in fungal taxonomy, but groups working on different clades can implement and recommend specific sequence-based tools for classification and identification.  Fungal taxonomists must work with users in mind in developing tools for SBC and SBI, to ensure the highest impact of their work. It is broadly recognized that the major barcode marker for Fungi, the ITS region, is a very useful (but blunt) instrument that merits status as a universal tool for fungal SBI, but it requires judicious use.  Multilocus approaches for SBC and SBI have been very effectively adopted in Fungi, and NGS techniques are well-suited for this approach.
